awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Single Cell Signaling Dynamics During Cell Fate Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells make critical decisions such as whether to proliferate or die by constantly evaluating their internal and external environment. Understanding how cells make these decisions is still an open question that can be addressed by combining quantitative biology and mathematical modelling. This project tackles long standing questions in cell fate determination by using a new technology that allows measuring biochemical changes inside individual cells in real time as they make decisions. The interdisciplinary nature of this project, combining molecular and cell biology, protein engineering, advanced imaging, and mathematical modeling, makes it particularly well-suited for educational purposes.  This will foster a unique training environment to introduce high school, undergraduate and graduate students to the field of single-cell quantitative biology.

MAPKs are key signaling molecules that orchestrate cellular responses to a diverse array of stimuli through a signaling network that ultimately controls gene expression, cell cycle or cell migration. The current understanding of how this highly interconnected network controls cellular decisions is incomplete because of: (i) a lack of methods to quantify the activity multiple signaling proteins in real time and (ii) the use of cell population assays that average unsynchronized single cell behaviors. To address this need, this project will pioneer a new generation of biosensors that allow simultaneous quantification of multiple protein activities in thousands of live single cells. The central hypothesis is that the signaling equilibrium between MAPKs is critical to regulate single cell outcomes (i.e. proliferation, quiescence, senescence, apoptosis). Using endpoint cell fate analysis, the researchers will be able to dissect the signaling patterns that underlie cell fate choices. In combination with mathematical modelling, this project aims to understand the fundamental principles of MAPK signaling dynamics that govern cellular decision making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Regot laboratory is interested in understanding cellular decisions in the context of noise. Through genetic and biochemical approaches coupled with powerful fluorescent biosensors and live cell imaging, we aim to define new biological mechanisms that govern cell signaling. As part of this NSF CAREER award we have published 6 papers covering different aspects of cellular decision making. Specifically, we have focused on the Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase (MAPK) network which is a widely conserved network of kinases across all eukaryotes that is involved in virtually all aspects of cell biology. In humans, the MAPK network is comprised of 24 MAP3Ks (upstream kinases with various regulatory domains connected to upstream molecular events), 7 MAP2Ks (intermediate phosphor-relay kinases for signal amplification), and 14 MAPKs (effector kinases that modulate cell behavior by targeting transcription factors and other regulators). Dysregulation of this highly interconnected network of kinases lies at the core of some of the most devastating human diseases including cancer, autoimmunity, and neurodegeneration. We have systematically surveyed all the MAP3Ks in the human genome and found that each elicits unique combinatorial patterns of downstream MAPK activities that drive opposing cell fates (i.e. apoptosis vs. proliferation). These MAPK activity combinations explain the paradoxical dual role of JNK signaling as either pro-apoptotic or pro-proliferative: JNK activation in combination with ERK (e.g. by Mixed Lineage Kinases (MLKs)) promotes proliferation, while JNK activation in combination with p38 (e.g. by TAK1 or ZAK) promotes cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. This foundational work has shifted our focus from MAP kinases to MAP3 Kinases as the ultimate, yet understudied, controllers of cell fate choices.

The cross-disciplinary nature of our work, combining molecular and cell biology, protein engineering, advanced imaging, image analysis and mathematical modeling, makes it particularly well-suited for educational purposes. As part of our broader impacts we have participated in numerous outreach activities including project BRIDGE, THREAD, and MERIT initiatives targeting different students groups from K-12. At the graduate education level we have created new quantitative biology courses to train future generations of scientist in the use of data rich approaches.
